facts.text: Petitioner carries on business of printing, publishing and selling text books for Primary, Middle schools and Higher Secondary classes in Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner carries on business of printing, publishing and selling text books for use in Primary, Middle schools and Higher Secondary classes in schools in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: New State of Madhya Pradesh formed on 1st November, 1956 under States Reorganization Act, 1956 comprising Mahakoshal, Madhya Bharat (excl. Sunel Tappa), Sironj Sub-Division of Kotah District in Rajasthan, Bhopal and Vindhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: On 1st November, 1956, as a result of the reorganisation of States under the States Reorganization Act, 1956, a new State of Madhya Pradesh was formed companyprising of territories of the existing States of Madhya Pradesh known as Mahakoshal area, the territories of the existing State of Madhya Bharat, excluding Sunel Tappa, Sironj SubDivision of Kotah District in the existing State of Rajasthan and the territories of the existing States of Bhopal and Vindhya Pradesh.

facts.text: School education divided into Primary (classes I to V), Middle School (VI to VIII), Higher Secondary (IX to XI).

anchor.surface_text: Primay education companysists of classes I to V, Middle School, of classes VI to VIll and Higher Secondary of classes IX to XI.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Secondary Education Act, 1959 enacted.

anchor.surface_text: barring a short period upto the enactment of the Madhya Pradesh Secondary Education Act, 1959  hereinafter referred to as the Act of 1959

facts.text: State Government prescribed courses of instruction and syllabi for Primary and Middle school education, followed by private schools for recognition and grants.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government prescribed the companyrses of instruction and syllabi for all classes of Primary and Middle school education and they were followed number only by Government schools but also by private schools, number because of any statutory authority, but because most of the private schools depended on grant-in-aid from the State Government

facts.text: State Government prescribed 29 text books for Primary and Middle school classes, accepted by private schools to avoid loss of grants.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the text books for use in Primary and Middle school classes were company- cerned, the State Government prescribed 29 text books printed and published by it on different subjects for use in different classes.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Pathya Pustak Rachna Avam Shaikshinik Anusandhan Nigam (Text Books Corporation) formed by State Government, registered under MP Societies Act 1959, loan of Rs. 15 lacs provided.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime a Society called the Madhya Pradesh Pathya Pustak Rachna Avam Shaikshinik Anusandhan Nigam  hereinafter referred to as the Text Books Corporation  was formed by the State Government for the purpose of carrying on the work of printing, publishing and distributing text books for use in the Primary and Middle school classes in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Notification dated 18th May, 1971 by State Government prescribed new courses and syllabi for 1971-72.

anchor.surface_text: The State ,Government by a numberification dated 18th May, 1971 prescribed improved companyrses of instruction and syallabi in certain subjects to be followed from the academic year 1971-72

facts.text: Text Books Corporation printed and published 28 text books per new syllabi, prescribed by State Government notification dated 21st May, 1971 for 1971-72.

anchor.surface_text: The Text Books Corporation accordingly printed and published 28 text books in accordance with the new companyrses of instruction and syallabi and these 28 text books were prescribed by the State Government by a numberification dated 21st May, 1971 for use in the Primary and Middle school classes for the academic year 1971-72.

facts.text: Notification dated 10th May 1972 prescribed courses for 1972-73, same 28 text books continued.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrses of instruction and syallabi for the next academic year 1972-73 were prescribed by the State Government by a numberification dated 10th May 1972

facts.text: Order dated 23rd March 1973 prescribed 36 text books by Text Books Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: an order dated 23rd Match 1973 was issued by the State Government prescribing these 36 text books for use in the Primary and Middle school classes.

facts.text: MP Madhyamik Shiksha Adhiniyam 1965 enacted on 29th September 1965, repealed Act of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Madhya Pradesh Madhyamik Shiksha Adhiniyam 1965  here- inafter referred to as the Act of 1965  was enacted by the Madhya Pradesh Legislature on 29th September 1965 and by s. 30, it repealed the Act of 1959.

facts.text: Board of Secondary Education prescribed text books in languages (English, Hindi, Marathi, Sanskrit) based on Text Books Committee selections under Act 1959.

anchor.surface_text: the Board, on the basis of the selections made by the Text Books Committee, prescribed text books in English, Hindi, Marathi and Sanskrit.

facts.text: Board recommended text books on Civics (5 Apr 1972), Economics (25 Apr 1972), Physics (26 Apr 1972), Chemistry (17 May 1972) for classes IX-X.

anchor.surface_text: The first was a numberification dated 5th April, 1972 by which the Board recommended six textbooks on Civics, the second was a numberification dated 25th April, 1972 by which the Board recommended five text books on Economics, the third was a numberification dated 26th April, 1972 by which the Board recommended eight text books on Physics and the fourth was a numberification dated 17th May, 1972 by which the Board recommended eight text books on Chemistry.

facts.text: Petitioner's text books on Civics, Physics, Chemistry rejected by reviewers for being below standard, poor paper, costlier.

anchor.surface_text: None of the text books prescribed or recommended by the Board was a text book printed and published, by the petitioner. The petitioner had submitted text books on Civics, Physics and Chemistry. for selection by the Board but they were rejected by the reviewers as they were found to be below standard

facts.text: MP Prathamik, Middle School Tatha Madhyamik Shiksha Pathya Pustakon Sambandhi Vyavastha Adhiniyam, 1973 (Act of 1973) came into force on 23rd March 1973.

anchor.surface_text: This Act came into force on 23rd March, 1973 being the date appointed under sub-s.  3  of s.

facts.text: Board notification dated 28th March 1973 continued previous text books for 1976 exam except General English and Tamil.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after the companying into force of the Act of 1973, the Board issued a numberification dated 28th March, 1973 which companytained inter alia the following directions The syllabus and scheme of examination for the Higher Secondary School Certificate Examination 1976 shall companytinue as per the Higher Secondary School Certificate Examination, 1975

facts.text: State Government notification dated 24th May 1973 approved text books on Botany, Zoology, History, Element of Commerce, English for 1976 exam in consultation with Board (recited).

anchor.surface_text: The State Government thereafter in exercise of the power companyferred under s. 4, sub-s.  1  of the Act of 1973 issued a numberification dated 24th May, 1973 according its approval to certain text books on Botany, Zoology, History, Element of Commerce and English for the Higher Secondary School Certificate Examination, 1976.

facts.text: Court held 28 text books by Text Books Corporation validly prescribed under executive power under Art 162, in force before appointed day.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore follow that 28 text books printed and published by the Text Books Corporation were validly and lawfully prescribed by the State Government in exercise of its executive power and they were in force immediately before the appointed day

facts.text: Court held Board had no power to prescribe text books on languages, ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore, clear, and this companyclusion can be disputed, that the prescription of text books on languages was outside the power of the Board and hence it was ultra vires and had numberbinding effect

facts.text: Court held recommended text books (Civics etc.) not prescribed, no obligation to use.

anchor.surface_text: These text books companyld number accordingly be regarded as prescribed text books either under sub-s.  1  or under sub-s.  2  of s. 4, and section 4, sub-s.  3  companyld number be invoked

facts.text: Court held notification 24 May 1973 invalid for lack of prior consultation with Board.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear beyond doubt that there was numberprior companysultation with the Boara before the State Government issued the numberification, dated 24th May, 1973 and this numberification must accordingly be held to be invalid

issues.text: Whether the State Government was entitled to prescribe the 28 textbooks printed and published by the Text Books Corporation for primary and middle school classes prior to the enactment of the Act of 1973 in exercise of its executive power under Article 162 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: executive power under Art. 162 of the Constitution. The executive power of the State Government under Art. 162 extends to all matters with respect to which the State Legislature has power to make laws and since education is a subject which falls within entry 11

issues.text: Whether the Board of Secondary Education had the power under the Act of 1965 to prescribe textbooks in languages, as necessarily implied in its power to prescribe courses of instruction?

anchor.surface_text: the prescription of text books on languages was outside the power of the Board and hence it was ultra vires and had no binding effect

issues.text: Whether textbooks merely recommended by the Board qualify as 'prescribed' textbooks in force immediately before the appointed day under section 4(2) of the Act of 1973?

anchor.surface_text: The Notification dated 28th March, 1973 undoubtedly provided that these textbooks shall be prescribed text books for the period commencing from the academic year 1973-74, but that Notification was ineffective

issues.text: Whether section 4 of the Act of 1973 violates Article 14 of the Constitution by conferring arbitrary and unguided power on the State Government?

arguments.claim: State Government had no statutory authority to prescribe 28 textbooks for primary and middle schools prior to Act 1973; notifications dated 21 May 1971 and 10 May 1972 invalid; not in force before appointed day

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the enactment of the Act of 1973 the State Government had numberstatutory authority to prescribe any text books for the primary and middle school classes and the numberifications dated 21st May, 1971 and 10th May, 1972 issued by the State Government prescribing 28 text books printed and published by the Text books Corporation for use in some of the primary and middle school classes were, therefore, without the authority of law

arguments.court_reasoning: State could prescribe under executive power Art 162 as education state subject; no infringement of private rights per Ram Jawaya precedent

arguments.claim: Board had no statutory authority to prescribe textbooks on languages; prescription invalid, not in force before appointed day

anchor.surface_text: Though text books on languages were prescribed by the Board, there was numberstatutory provision empowering the Board to do so and the prescription of these text books by the Board was, therefore, without the authority of law

arguments.court_reasoning: No express or implied power from prescribing courses; ultra vires

arguments.claim: Board's notification 28 March 1973 ineffective to prescribe textbooks under s.4(1) as issued by Board not State; recommended books not prescribed

anchor.surface_text: The Notification dated 28th March, 1973 undoubtedly provided that these textbooks shall be prescribed text books for the period companymencing from the academic year 1973-74, but that Notification was ineffective to prescribe any text books under s. 4, sub-s.  1  because it was issued by the Board

arguments.court_reasoning: Only State can prescribe under s.4(1); Board's notification futile

arguments.claim: Recommended textbooks on Civics etc. by Board notifications Apr-May 1972 not prescribed, not in force before appointed day; 28 Mar 1973 not effective

anchor.surface_text: The Board by issuing the numberifications dated 5th April, 1972, 25th April, 1972, 26th April, 1972 and 17th May, 1972 merely recommended certain text books on Civics, Economics, Physics and Chemistry. These text books were number prescribed by the Board

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction between recommend and prescribe; no binding obligation

arguments.claim: Notification 24 May 1973 invalid for lack of prior consultation with Board as required by proviso to s.4(1)

anchor.surface_text: Though the numberification dated 24th May, 1973 recited that the approval to the text books mentioned in the- numberification was accorded by the State Government in companysultation with the Board, there was in fact numberprior companysultation with the Board

arguments.court_reasoning: Recital presumption rebutted; Chairman's action not Board's; no delegation via resolution

arguments.claim: Section 4 violates Art 19(1)(g) as imposes unreasonable restrictions; no proper machinery, unguided discretion

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 imposed unreasonable restrictions on the right of the petitioner to carry on his business of printing publishing and distributing text books for use in Primary, Middle School and Higher Secondary Classes, inasmuch as it did number provide a proper and adequate machinery

arguments.court_reasoning: No fundamental right to have books prescribed; per Ram Jawaya, mere chance incidental to trade

arguments.claim: Section 4 violates Art 14; enables discrimination, no standards, arbitrary power

anchor.surface_text: This section was also violative of the equality clause companytained in Art. 14 of the Constitution inasmuch as it enabled the State Government to discriminate between one publisher and another by leaving it to the unrestrained will of the State Government

arguments.court_reasoning: Guided by policy of uniformity and excellence; not unguided; standards from object/purpose

arguments.claim: Power to prescribe courses of instruction in languages implies power to prescribe textbooks
arguments.court_reasoning: Courses can be prescribed without specific textbooks; grammar etc. by topics; prose/poetry by references not editions

arguments.claim: Chairman entitled to act on behalf of Board; his recommendations = Board's consultation

anchor.surface_text: the Chairman was entitled to act on behalf of the Board in making recommendations and the recommendations made by him in regard to text books were in the eye of the Jaw recommendations of the Board

arguments.court_reasoning: No statutory delegation; resolution invalid; only via regulations

anchor.surface_text: by this decision the Board authorised the Chairman to take all necessary steps for the purpose of proceeding further with the work of the text books im- provement scheme which companysisted of selection and approval of text books

arguments.court_reasoning: Board cannot delegate by resolution; only via regulations; post-dates power anyway

No infringement of private rights by prescribing textbooks; mere chance incidental to trade per Ram Jawaya

arguments.claim: S.4 not violates Art 19(1)(g); no right to prescription

anchor.surface_text: The challenges based on Art. 19 1   g  must, therefore, fail.

arguments.claim: S.4 not violates Art 14; power guided by uniformity/excellence policy

holdings.text: 28 text books printed and published by the Text Books Corporation were validly and lawfully prescribed by the State Government in exercise of its executive power and they were in force immediately before the appointed day.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore follow that 28 text books printed and published by the Text Books Corporation were validly and lawfully prescribed by the State Government in exercise of its executive power and they were in force immediately before the appointed day

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executive power under Art 162 extends to education (State List entry 11); no infringement of private rights as no vested right in prescription per Ram Jawaya precedent; private schools need recognition/grants.

holdings.text: the prescription of text books on languages was outside the power of the Board and hence it was ultra vires and had no binding effect

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore, clear, and this conclusion can be disputed, that the prescription of text books on languages was outside the power of the Board and hence it was ultra vires and had no binding effect

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express power in Act 1965; power to prescribe courses does not imply power to prescribe textbooks as courses can specify topics/works without specific editions.

holdings.text: These text books could not accordingly be regarded as prescribed text books either under sub-s. (1) or under sub-s. (2) of s. 4, and section 4, sub-s. (3) could not be invoked

anchor.surface_text: These text books could not accordingly be regarded as prescribed text books either under sub-s. (1) or under sub-s. (2) of s. 4, and section 4, sub-s. (3) could not be invoked

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between 'recommend' (persuasive, no obligation) and 'prescribe' (mandatory); Board's 28 Mar 1973 notification ineffective as issued by Board not State Govt.

holdings.text: there was no prior consultation with the Board before the State Government issued the notification, dated 24th May, 1973 and this notification must accordingly be held to be invalid

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear beyond doubt that there was no prior consultation with the Board before the State Government issued the notification, dated 24th May, 1973 and this notification must accordingly be held to be invalid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.4(1) mandates prior consultation as condition precedent; recital presumption rebutted by evidence; Chairman's recommendations not Board's (no delegation via resolution).

holdings.text: The challenges based on Art. 19(1)(g) must, therefore, fail.

anchor.surface_text: The challenges based on Art. 19(1)(g) must, therefore, fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fundamental right to have books prescribed; mere chance incidental to trade/business per Ram Jawaya; applies equally to statutory power.

holdings.text: It is not possible to say that arbitrary and uncontrolled power has been vested in the State Government and on that account s. 4, sub-s. (1) is bad.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Power guided by statutory object of uniformity/excellence in education; not unguided as standards from purpose; potential abuse addressable if occurs.

precedents.citation: Rai Sahib Ram Jawaya Kapur v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Rai Sahib Ram Jawaya Kapur v. State of Punjab 1 that the State Government can act in exercise of executive power in relation to any matter with respect to- which the State Legislature has power to make laws, even if there is numberlegislation to support such executive action, but such executive action must number infringe the rights of any person.

precedents.case_name: Rai Sahib Ram Jawaya Kapur v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: State Government can exercise executive power to prescribe textbooks without legislation if no private rights are infringed

precedents.cited_proposition: Executive action entering textbook business upheld as no prejudice

precedents.cited_proposition: No infringement of rights by government entering trade, mere chance not a right

precedents.cited_proposition: State prescription of textbooks valid under executive power

precedents.cited_proposition: No violation of Art 19(1)(g) by government nationalisation of textbooks

precedents.cited_proposition: No fundamental right infringed by government taking over textbook trade

anchor.surface_text: As said by this Court in Matajob Dobey v. H. C. Bhari l  A discretionary power is number necessarily a discriminatory power and abuse of power is number easily to be assumed where the discretion is vested in the Government and number in a minor official.

precedents.cited_proposition: Discretionary power vested in government not easily assumed discriminatory

precedents.cited_proposition: Best test of truth is free trade in ideas

justification_sets.label: Proviso to s.4(1), MP Madhyamik Shiksha Adhiniyam 1965 support

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear beyond doubt that there was no prior consultation with the Board before the State Government issued the notification, dated 24th May, 1973 and this notification must accordingly be held to be invalid as being in breach of the mandatory requirement of the proviso to s. 4, sub-s. 1 .

outcome.relief_summary: Notifications prescribing language textbooks by Board held ultra vires; recommended textbooks not prescribed; notification dated 24th May 1973 held invalid for lack of prior consultation with Board; Section 4 of Act of 1973 upheld as constitutional
directions: Textbooks prescribed by Board on languages held without authority and not binding
Recommended textbooks on Civics, Economics, Physics, Chemistry not prescribed and not binding
Notification dated 24th May, 1973 quashed for lack of prior consultation with Board
28 textbooks by Text Books Corporation validly prescribed under executive power

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore follow that 28 text books printed and published by the Text Books Corporation were validly and lawfully prescribed by the State Government in exercise of its executive power and they were in force immediately before the appointed day
